There is an ongoing commitment to implement changes, when identified, that will improve the safety of employees and neighbors of the Facility as well as projects that enhance safety, environmental protection and protect the community from exposure to accidental releases. Specific actions at the Sour Lake Olefins Facility that will be taken in the future to improve the level of safety include:
	Evaluating changes to the process using Management of Change procedures and Process Hazard Analysis tools to ensure any new hazards are identified and addressed appropriately.
	Continued implementation of effective Mechanical Integrity strategies on the process equipment and instrumentation.
	Addressing any internal audit findings with an appropriate sense of urgency to ensure worker and public safety is not adversely impacted.
	Maintaining an ongoing dialogue with the Hardin County Emergency Management Office, County Sheriff's Office, Sour Lake Volunteer Fire Department, and other emergency responders to ensure a constant state of readiness to respond to any potential emergencies, and a means to implement improvements as the need develops.
In this way, we shall bolster our strong commitment to the safety of our workers and the community.

This purpose is accomplished using the Terminal Operations Contractor Management Program.   

A few examples of the prevention measures in place at this facility include:
	Automated Instrumentation for level, flow, temperature, and pressure on the caverns and process area to prevent from exceeding operating limits of the caverns and process equipment and to automatically initiate a process shutdown or initiate an emergency facility shutdown as necessary.
	Maintenance and function testing of safety systems including:
	Protective devices identified in the Process Hazard Analysis.
	Emergency Shutdown Devices (ESDs) on the well heads and in the process area to stop the flow of ethylene, brine, and fresh water.
	Flammable gas detectors in the process and cavern areas that provide early detection of a release.
	Emergency backup generator and air compressor to minimize the potential for loss of process controls due to a utility outage.

4.	The Five-Year Accident History 
The Sour Lake Olefins Facility has had no accidental releases that would meet the criteria for an accidental release per 40 CFR 68.42.  

5.	The Emergency Response Program  
The Sour Lake Olefins Facility continues to conduct emergency response preparedness activities and coordinate any emergency response actions necessary with the Hardin County Emergency Management Office, County Sheriff's Office, Sour Lake Volunteer Fire Department, and other agencies assisting local officials. The facility has written emergency response programs that contain procedures to be followed in the case of an accidental release of a regulated substance. The emergency response plans are reviewed and updated as necessary at least annually and when changes at the facility could affect emergency response. The Sour Lake Volunteer Fire Department provides initial emergency response to the facility in the event of an accidental release.

Employees are encouraged to participate in the development and maintenance of specific components of process safety. g.	Pre-Startup Safety Review - Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs) are completed prior to implementing a change that involves new or revised process safety information.  Operations, Maintenance and Engineering employees may participate in final systems reviews (e.g., walk-downs, inspections, testing) prior to placing equipment into service as part of the PSSR process.

h.	Compliance Audits - The facility conducts compliance audits of the PSM/RMP Program.  Employees may participate in compliance audits in a number of ways, including being interviewed by the audit team and providing records, documents, and/or other information requested by the team.  Additionally, at least one employee with knowledge of the process is included on the audit team.

Refresher training is accomplished on the maintenance and operating procedures routinely which includes a review of these procedures.

The facility stores and processes ethylene (ethene) above the RMP threshold quantity of 10,000 lbs. The ethylene is stored in underground salt dome caverns and is processed by the facility to remove water and carbon dioxide associated with cavern storage such that it can be shipped via pipeline.  Brine water used in the cavern storage process is degassed of ethylene before being stored in brine ponds. 

3.	The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:

The Sour Lake Olefins Facility is operating under the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Plan (RMP) regulation, and the Railroad Commission of Texas (RRC) requirements for salt dome cavern storage. The potential for chemical release accidents is minimized through ongoing analysis of the potential hazards of the process, detailed training of employees, and emphasis on process safety. This program also involves identifying and taking steps to avoid potential accidental chemical releases. 

The procedural and management practices important to the prevention program include the following:

a.	Process Safety Information - Process Safety Information (PSI) is maintained for the chemicals, technology, and equipment used in the process.  Employees are involved in the development and review of PSI through normal job duties.   This includes, process safety information  documented in Safety Data Sheets, process flow diagrams, operating procedures, P&IDs, equipment design standards, and equipment data files.  PSI is  reviewed by employees participating in Process Hazards Analysis (PHA), operating procedure reviews, training, and Management of Change (MOC) processes as appropriate.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 
Sour Lake Olefins Facility, 6347 Stonewall Rd., Sour Lake, TX 77659

1.	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
The Sour Lake Olefins Facility is subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) of Highly Hazardous Chemicals and related OSHA standards.  The facility has expanded its programs to meet the Environmental Protection Agencys (EPAs) Risk Management Plan (RMP) Rule. These programs help maintain low levels of risks to our employees, contractors, the community, and the environment. This is achieved through: (1) minimizing the possibility of serious plant upsets through engineering and procedural safeguards and (2) thoroughly planning contingencies in coordination with local responding agencies.

The Sour Lake Olefins Facility is committed to managing all operations in a manner that protects the environment and the health and safety of employees, customers, contractors, and the public while fully complying with applicable laws and regulations.  Management philosophy goals are achieved through the implementation of its Environmental, Health, and Safety Management Systems, by the personal commitments of employees and contractors, and by open communication with employees, customers, neighbors, and regulators.   Furthermore, the Sour Lake Olefins Facility implements a series of provisions to prevent potential hazardous impacts associated with the processes at the facility. These measures include ensuring that the facility has a well-trained work force, maintaining onsite procedures and manuals, and coordinating with the Hardin County Emergency Management Office, County Sheriff's Office, Sour Lake Volunteer Fire Department, and other agencies to develop emergency response plans and to participate in cooperative emergency response training drills.
